title: Should I buy a refurbished laptop or a cheap new one? - Quora

response.answer_text: It really depends. Let’s start off by pointing out that $200 for a laptop is considered entry level… BUDGET entry level. Almost to the point of being a Chromebook. Not hating on that particular device, but it should be noted that it is limited when compared to an actual laptop computer. That said, if the refurbished device you’re considering has better specs than the new ones for thew same price, and it’s from a reputable source (Newegg, TigerDirect, what have you) then by all means go ahead. If it fails within that companies specified return period, they’ll swap you a new (refurbished) one. I have made 2 such purchases. One, made almost 10 years ago was a Lenovo Z61t that I still have to this day. I’ve had to replace the keyboard, battery, and ribbon cable that drives the display in that time. In all fairness, that could have just have easily have happened with a brand new unit in that time frame. That unit cost me under $200 from Newegg. It still does everything I need it to do. About 2 years ago, I purchased an Acer… Thing. Not really a laptop, not really a tablet. Has a touchscreen and a detachable keyboard, so I guess it’s more of a tablet. I got it refurbished for $160. This was right around when Windows 10 came out, and updating it killed it. They sent me a new (refurbished) one with minimal headache. Purchasing refurbished items really is a crap-shoot. Something to consider is whether or not you can live without the device if it fails and you have to wait up to 3 weeks for yours to ship back so they can determine that you didn’t dump a soda into it, and send you a new one. You wouldn’t want that if this was your daily driver. One last thing: If you do go the route you’re considering, I have one piece of advice. Buy a SSD and max out the RAM. You’d be surprised to see the huge difference these two things make. They’re super easy to do yourself, don’t cost much (although RAM has really spiked lately) and the performance boost is staggering. YouTube search your model number and the keywords upgrading RAM, or installing SSD and you’ll find an applicable video. It literally takes under 15 minutes. Good luck! A
